awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A Cost-Effective Per- and Polyfluoroalkyl Substance (PFAS_ Electrolyzer for Groundwater Remediation
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is in providing safe, cost-effective elimination of per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) from groundwater in order to protect human health and the environment while reducing the cost and complexity of remediation. PFAS are some of the world’s most intractable pollutants and have contaminated groundwater and drinking water sources across the US and the world.  The toxicity, mobility, and bioaccumulation of PFAS pose a need for remediation as they cause an array of adverse impacts on human health. PFAS in groundwater cannot be broken down through traditional chemical processes; Hence, current PFAS treatment options are non-destructive, expensive, and simply transfer the PFAS to a solid or concentrated waste stream where the efficacy and safety of disposal are still uncertain.  This project focuses on the development of a low cost, sustainable treatment method that eliminates PFAS with no secondary waste generation and no costly consumables.  This technology removes the liability and environmental and health risks associated with incomplete elimination and secondary waste disposal.

The objective of this SBIR Phase 1 project is to develop a safe, chemical-free and low cost PFAS electrolyzer for groundwater remediation. The electrolyzer consists of a divided radial-field unit cell architecture with a de-polarized cathode and a high surface area and low-cost anode electrocatalyst material. The electrocatalyst is designed to provide direct oxidation at high voltage and the treatment process will mineralize PFAS in a single step, in minutes, with no breakdown byproducts or secondary waste. A scalable, single unit cell bench-top electrolyzer will be designed and built for treatability testing of PFAS-contaminated groundwater.  The anode electrocatalyst material composition will be optimized and coated onto high surface area substrates.  A de-polarized cathode will be developed to eliminate the catholyte loop and hydrogen generation, and lower energy consumption. The PFAS mineralization effectiveness will be measured as a function of operating parameters and water quality.  The electrocatalytic performance and the degradation mechanism of the new anode material will be determined. Using the experimental results, the capital and operating cost of a groundwater remediation system will be estimated.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Per- and Polyfluoroalkyl Substances (PFASs) are one of the world's most intractable pollutants that have contaminated groundwater and drinking water sources across the US and the world. The toxicity, mobility and bioaccumulation of PFASs pose an urgent need for remediation to safeguard human health.  More than 200 million Americans are estimated to have PFAS contaminated drinking water. The annual health care costs and associated economic costs of exposure to long-chain PFAS in the US is estimated to be over $5 billion.  Not only are the health care costs substantial, but the total cost of global PFAS clean-up is enormous and is estimated to reach a trillion dollars using current, non-destructive methods.

PFASs in groundwater and drinking water sources cannot be broken down through traditional biological or chemical processes; therefore, the proven remedial options currently available are non-destructive, expensive, and simply transfer the PFASs to a solid or concentrated waste stream.  Hence, there is a need to develop a destructive PFAS remediation process that is efficacious, safe, cost-effective, and does not create an unmanageable waste stream to reduce human exposure to these chemicals.  

In this project, OXbyEL successfully met its objectives. The technical feasibility of a scalable, safe, and chemical-free radial field-flow PFAS Electrolyzer for PFAS destruction of contaminated water was proven. The process achieved single-step, total organic fluorine (TOF) mineralization with no secondary PFAS short-chain byproducts and no secondary waste. The end products of destruction are safe, and commonly found in carbonated spring water. The mineralization effectiveness for both long and short-chain PFASs was maintained in a variety of background water matrices and the PFAS chemicals were destroyed in minutes. Accelerated durability testing verified the lifetime of the low-cost anode electrocatalyst developed in this project was equivalent to the most expensive commercial catalyst available. The cost competitiveness of the process was confirmed for groundwater remediation with an estimated treatment cost 4-5X lower than non-destructive granular activated carbon. 

The broader impact of this technology will be the reduction of human exposure to PFAS chemicals protecting the health of Americans and people world-wide, the protection of the environment from contamination, the reduction of the global health care and economic burden, and a reduction of the cost and complexity of remediation.
